Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Field Research on Bahamian Lakes: Exploring Records of Anthropogenic and Climatic Change
Award.AbstractNarration:
The goal of the Bahamian Lakes REU site is to provide undergraduate students a fieldwork and laboratory opportunity to learn first-hand about Earth as a system and to develop skills in conducting and communicating scientific research through studying modern limnologic systems and the environmental, geochemical, and biological records of change recovered from lake sediment cores. We will target sophomore to junior-level undergraduate geoscience and pre-service teacher participants from urban comprehensive universities in the Great Lakes and mid-continent region. Our regional recruitment will allow us to encourage students of color from urban areas to participate as well as facilitating participants to present their research at a common North-Central section meeting of the Geological Society of America. We anticipate that this REU experience will positively influence participants to complete a baccalaureate degree and pursue graduate work.

Understanding the dynamics of human-climate interaction remains one of society's looming unanswered questions. The role of natural climate variability and how it may differ from how humans may have changed their environment and driven localized changes to climate is a leading area of global change research. Our faculty will mentor students in the collection, analyses, and interpretation of data from the modern subtropical lake systems and past records of environmental change from sedimentary cores recovered from lakes in the Bahamas. These data will be compared to stratigraphic, biological, and chemical records derived from archaeologically excavations in order to decipher the footprint of human occupation and how it may have impacted the physical and biological environments. These data will be used to build a deeper understanding of the history and nature of climatic and anthropogenic environmental change through time.

The Bahamian Lakes REU site has the potential of increasing both the number of women and under-represented minorities completing gesoscience undergraduate degrees and continuing on to graduate programs. We believe that our international collaboration with the College of the Bahamas and the Bahamian Antiquities, Monuments, and Museums Corporation and the international nature of the fieldwork will provide an unparalleled avenue for cultural enrichment for the students as well as an experience in global cooperation that will be invaluable for a student's future success in an increasingly global workforce and economy.

This award is funded by the Division of Earth Sciences and the Office of International Science and Engineering.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this REU project was to provide an integrated and multidisciplinary undergraduate research experience in paleoclimate and paleoenvironmental reconstruction from lake deposit records in the Bahamas for the past 6000 years. The project integrated stratigraphic, biological, and chemical records derived from sediment cores with archaeological excavations to examine the impact of climate change on human occupation and migration in the Bahamian archipelago. This project was designed to build a deeper understanding of the history and nature of climatic and environmental change through this critical time window. In addition, we wanted to provide a comprehensive and culturally enriched learning experience for the students participating in the project and expose them to a diverse amount of activities and engagement opportunities to both focus and enhance their participation in science and in choosing science for their career.

 

Our long term (~6000 years) hurricane and climate change record in the Bahamas corresponds with global and regional records and indicates a vegetation shift from a dry to wet period (tropical hardwoods) to pine dominated canopies and introduction of new taxa.  The Lucayan period began when the dry period ended and had two periods of high storm intensities. Coastal ponds such as Shad and Triangle Pond were initiated as a coastal mangrove swamps fronted by a welded barrier at approximately 3700 ybp.  This corresponds with mollusk bed depths that show a rapid rise in sea level during that time as well as another rapid rise and subsequent fall at ~2500 year BP.  Truncations of berm strata and density lags at the scarp base accentuate their recognition in the field and in geophysical (georadar) records. Shad and Triangle Ponds, like many of the coastal lakes in the Bahamas, were formed by tempestites that acted as nucleation sites for dune emplacement during and after large storm events followed by the accumulation of landward-thinning backdune lithosomes over a shallow beachrock platform, supporting the retrogradation of the proto-barriers as a mechanism for the isolation of the pond, with likely intermittent stages as a lagoon occasionally connected to the ocean via inlet(s). It is likely that Lucayan occupation was influenced by the position of paleoshorelines, and Shad and Triangle Ponds, as well other lakes, were probably hypersaline at the time of their arrival and throughout their inhabitance, corresponding with the Medieval Warm Period 1200-1000 yBP.

 

In addition to coastal ponds, three blue holes were cored on San Salvador and Eleuthera. Downcore data indicates grain size changes along with mollusk distribution that is likely linked to sea level. Mollusk faunas are similar between the blue holes and include 3 species of bivalves and 8 species of gastropods. X-ray fluorescence (XRF) scans of the cores reveal negatively co-varying trends between Fe and Ca. There is an overall increase in Sr that is independent of Ca and corresponding with increases in organic matter. We used depths of mollusk beds to reconstruct a sea level curve for the past 6000 years BP, that indicate a rapid rise at 2500 cal yBP that has not been previously reported from the Bahamas.

 

Our results can be useful to atmospheric modelers and groundwater hydrologists because of the connections between climate change and sea level fluctuations. Our pollen records are of interest to botanists and conservation biologists who would like to know the baseline flora before human occupation and climate and sea level change. In addition, archaeologists would be very interested in our climate record as well as pollen and charcoal records since they indicate the conditions when the Lucayans were first migrating and inhabiting the islands.  Coastal geomorphologists would also be interested in our GPR data ...
